content:
To her everlasting credit, Elizabeth has different ideas. She hasn’t had a lot of sex in her life, and even less great sex, but as she enters her 30s, is pretty damn clear that tremendous chemistry is out there waiting for her. Waiting with someone else.
 
 Fourteen months into our marriage, Elizabeth asks for a divorce. I try to argue. “I’m doing this for you too,” she say. “I deserve a man whose clothes I want to rip off. And you deserve a woman who gets wet when she looks at you.”
 
 There is no arguing with that.
 
 One night, shortly before I move out for good, I ask Elizabeth if she is sorry we’d stopped having sex before we were married. She thinks for a moment. 
 
 “Yes,” she says, “I really wish you hadn’t told me we could wait.” 
 
 I nod. I don’t need to ask why. Elizabeth smiles. “But it was so sweet of you to try,” she adds.
 
 I will never underestimate the centrality of chemistry again.
